content.body: The sad part, you have to do this even if you're using typescript
it’d be weird if typescript could magically implement overloads for you
would likely end up with C++ name mangling and having to annotate functions meant to interop with regular JavaScript as “extern”
That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as `function foo(index, name=index)` today, if i'm reading correctly
content.formatted_body: That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as function foo(index, name=index) today, if i'm reading correctly

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as `function foo(index, name=index)` today, if i'm reading correctly
That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as function foo(index, name=index) today, if i'm reading correctly

content.body:
> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as `function foo(index, name=index)` today, if i'm reading correctly

Note that the example sets `name` to `index` if `name` is undefined. So it’s not similar to `function foo(index, name=index)`; it’s basically `function foo(«optional index», name)`.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
That example just shows ordinary end-of-signature optionality, doesn't it? you could just write it as function foo(index, name=index) today, if i'm reading correctly
Note that the example sets name to index if name is undefined. So it’s not similar to function foo(index, name=index); it’s basically function foo(«optional index», name).

content.body: ??? You just explained what my code did, then gave an example that didn't match.
